coredata.dc:description: This study investigated the effects of electrode wettability on hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) production from oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) during electrolysis with superaerophilic electrodes. When the electrode was in the underwater Wenzel-Cassie (UWC) state, it could quickly adsorb aerated oxygen microbubbles, which significantly enhanced oxygen transfer. Meanwhile, H2O2 reduction was effectively inhibited. Consequently, high ORR currents and current efficiencies (CEs) of H2O2 production could be obtained in the UWC state. However, oxygen can only be transferred to the electrode by dissolved oxygen (DO) diffusion when the electrode was in the underwater Wenzel (UW) state. Due to the slow DO diffusion and enhanced H2O2 reduction at the wetted electrode, the rate and CEs of H2O2 production decreased dramatically in the UW state. Maintaining a stable UWC state by controlling the rate of O2 bubbling and rate of O2 consumption in ORR is thus critical to maximizing H2O2 electrosynthesis with the superaerophilic electrodes.

head.ce:title: Maximizing electrochemical hydrogen peroxide production from oxygen reduction with superaerophilic electrodes

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: This study investigated the effects of electrode wettability on hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) production from oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) during electrolysis with superaerophilic electrodes. When the electrode was in the underwater Wenzel-Cassie (UWC) state, it could quickly adsorb aerated oxygen microbubbles, which significantly enhanced oxygen transfer. Meanwhile, H2O2 reduction was effectively inhibited. Consequently, high ORR currents and current efficiencies (CEs) of H2O2 production could be obtained in the UWC state. However, oxygen can only be transferred to the electrode by dissolved oxygen (DO) diffusion when the electrode was in the underwater Wenzel (UW) state. Due to the slow DO diffusion and enhanced H2O2 reduction at the wetted electrode, the rate and CEs of H2O2 production decreased dramatically in the UW state. Maintaining a stable UWC state by controlling the rate of O2 bubbling and rate of O2 consumption in ORR is thus critical to maximizing H2O2 electrosynthesis with the superaerophilic electrodes.

ce:section.ce:para: Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is an important reagent used in various advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) for water and wastewater treatment, e.g., the peroxone (O3/H2O2), ultraviolet/H2O2 (UV/H2O2), and Fenton (Fe2+/H2O2) processes [1,2]. However, H2O2 stock solutions (â¼30â70 wt.%) produced from the conventional anthraquinone process are dangerous to transport, store, and handle due to the potential risks of explosion and corrosion [1,3]. To enhance the feasibility of H2O2-based AOPs, electrochemical production of H2O2 from oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) has been proposed a promising way to produce H2O2 on site and on demand for water and wastewater treatment. Unlike the conventional anthraquinone oxidation process, which requires large infrastructure and generates considerable waste chemicals [3â5], electrochemical H2O2 production from ORR is a small-footprint and essentially zero-waste process [1]. In addition, many studies have demonstrated that H2O2 can be produced from ORR at comparable or lower electricity costs than the sales prices of H2O2 stocks [6â8]. These favorable characteristics make electrochemical oxygen reduction an attractive alternative to supply H2O2 for water and wastewater treatment, especially for decentralized applications such as distributed water treatment (point-of-entry/use) at a household or community level [1,9â12].

To date, a great variety of electrocatalysts have been developed for H2O2 production from ORR under varying reaction conditions, including noble metals, single-atom catalysts, conducting polymers, organic coordination compounds, metal compounds, and carbon-based materials [13â16]. Among these electrocatalysts, carbonaceous materials are the most commonly used in electrochemical processes for water treatment (e.g., the electro-Fenton (EF) and electro-peroxone (EP) processes) because of their abundance, low cost, high selectivity for two-electron ORR to H2O2, non-toxicity, and other favorable properties [9,17â20]. Various carbon-based electrodes have been tested for H2O2 production during water treatment, for example, graphite felt [21â25], carbon felt (CF) [26â28], activated carbon fiber (ACF) [29], carbon black-polytetrafluoroethylene (CB-PTFE) [30â32], reticulated vitreous carbon (RVC) [33,34] and carbon sponge (CS) [35]. These carbon-based electrodes are usually used in two general setups during electrochemical water treatment: (i) submerged and aerated electrode (SAE) and (ii) gas diffusion electrode (GDE), which differs mainly in the way of oxygen/air supply [9,36]. The SAEs are usually made of large surface area carbonaceous materials (e.g., CF, ACF, and RVC) and are directly submerged in electrolytes aerated with O2/air. The aerated oxygen gas is first dissolved in the solutions, then further transferred from the bulk solution to the cathode surface, where it is reduced to H2O2 [9]. In contrast, the GDEs are usually assembled electrodes that consist of a carbon-based electrode (typically CB-PTFE), gas chamber, gaskets, and other parts. During electrolysis, O2 is first fed to the gas chamber, then diffuses through the porous CB-PTFE structure to the other side of the electrode in contact with electrolytes, where it reacts with H+/H2O and electrons to form H2O2 in the electrochemical cell [2,9,37]. Despite the high efficiency of oxygen transfer in GDEs, GDEs are currently less commonly used in electrochemical processes for water and wastewater treatment due to several challenges in scaling up the GDEs for practical applications (e.g., electrode breakage and water flooding) [2,38]. In comparison, the SAEs have a simpler configuration and are easier to operate. Therefore, they are now the most commonly used electrode setup in electrochemical water treatment processes [2,9,18]. Nevertheless, the rate of H2O2 production is often limited by the low solubility of O2 and the slow diffusion of dissolved O2 (DO) to the ORR active sites of SAE cathodes [2,39].

Notably, recent studies on the four-electron ORR to H2O in the fuel cell area have shown that by fabricating high roughness nanoarray-based surface, superaerophilic electrodes can be obtained [40â42]. The superaerophilic electrodes have a high gas affinity and can thus retain certain amounts of air at their textured surface when they are immersed in water. The electrode, trapped gas, and water then form an underwater solid/liquid/gas tri-phase interface, which greatly facilitates the interfacial oxygen and electron transfer processes involved in ORR. Consequently, high ORR currents can be achieved to accelerate ORR to H2O during electrolysis with the superaerophilic electrodes [40]. These findings suggest that superaerophilic electrodes may also have great potential as the SAEs to enhance the performance of electrochemical H2O2 production from two-electron ORR, although different electrocatalysts are used for the two- and four-electron ORR (e.g., carbon-based and platinum-based electrocatalysts, respectively).

Maximizing the underwater solid/liquid/gas tri-phase interface is critical to achieve the high kinetics of ORR to H2O during electrolysis with the superaerophilic electrodes [40,41]. According to the previous studies, a maximized tri-phase interface can be obtained when the superaerophilic electrodes are in the underwater Wenzel-Cassie (UWC) wetting state, where water is partially intruded into the pores on the electrode surface (see Fig. 1 b), with the trapped gas existing as a thin gas film or gas pockets at the surface. In contrast, excessive increase or decrease of the trapped gas will transform the electrode wetting state to the underwater Cassie (UC) or underwater Wenzel (UW) state, where the electrode is either hardly wetted by the electrolyte due to the presence of a thick, quasi-continuous gas film over its surface (Fig. 1a), or is completely wetted by the electrolyte without trapped gas at the electrode/liquid interface (Fig. 1c). Due to the lack of tri-phase interface, the rate of ORR to H2O decreased dramatically for the superaerophilic electrodes in the UC and UW state compared to that in the UWC state [41]. Overall, the previous studies focused mainly on tuning the surface roughness of superaerophilic electrodes to achieve different initial wetting states (UC, UWC, and UW) and then comparing their performance for ORR to H2O [40]. However, the evolution of electrode wetting state and its effects on oxygen transfer and electrode reaction selectivity during ORR has not been well explored. As electrode wetting is a dynamic process and may change between the different wetting states during electrolysis [41,43], more studies are needed to investigate how to maintain a stable UWC state for the superaerophilic electrode to enhance the performance of electrochemical H2O2 production from ORR.

The main objective of this study was to evaluate the evolution of wetting state of superaerophilic electrodes and its effect on electrochemical H2O2 production from ORR. CB-PTFE electrodes with a superaerophilic surface were prepared using a facile method and then tested for electrochemical H2O2 production in the SAE setup. The evolution of electrode wetting state during electrolysis was evaluated under varying test conditions. A close correlation between the transition of electrode wetting state and the change of ORR currents was observed during electrolysis with the superaerophilic electrodes. The results were then discussed based on the different oxygen transfer mechanisms observed in the different wetting state. The findings of this study offer useful information for proper gas management to maximize H2O2 production from ORR with the superaerophilic electrodes.

CB-PTFE electrodes were fabricated with Vulcan XC-72R carbon black powder (Cabot Corp., USA), PTFE dispersion (60 wt.%), and anhydrous ethanol using the protocol described by Wang et al. [44]. First, 6 g of carbon black was mixed with 80 mL of anhydrous ethanol in an ultrasonic bath for 10 min. Then 10 mL of PTFE dispersion was added, followed by 15 min ultrasonication. Next, the mixture was heated in a water bath at 80 Â°C to evaporate ethanol. The resulting CB-PTFE paste was rolled into a thin sheet with a thickness of 2 mm and then cut into several rectangular slices (2 cm Ã 5 cm). Two pieces of the CB-PTFE slices, with a piece of nickel mesh in their middle as the current collector, was pressed together under 20 MPa pressure for 1 min. Finally, the CB-PTFE electrode was calcined at 350 Â°C for 1 h at a heating rate of 5 Â°C minâ1 in a muffle furnace.

The surface microstructures of the CB-PTFE electrode were investigated using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Sigma500, Germany) and atomic force microscope (AFM, Bruker, Germany). The chemical composition and elemental mapping of CB-PTFE electrode were investigated using energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS). The surface area and pore size distribution of the CB and CB-PTFE powder scrapped from the CB-PTFE electrode plate were measured by nitrogen adsorption and desorption at â196 Â°C using a Micrometrics ASAP 2460system. The surface area was calculated from Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation. Pore size distribution curves were obtained from the adsorption branch of N2 isotherm using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method and Density Functional Theory (DFT) method. The pore size distribution of the virgin and wetted CB-PTFE electrode plate was characterized by the mercury intrusion method using a mercury porosimeter (Micromeritics, AutoPore IV 9500), which can analyze porous media with a pore size ranging from 6 nm to 300 Î¼m [45]. Before the mercury intrusion experiment, the wetted electrode was naturally dried out in the air. The wettability of the electrode underwater was evaluated by the bubble contact angle using the captive bubble method with an optical video contact angle system (Dataphysics OCA25, Germany) [40]. The volume of the gas bubble for bubble contact angle measurement was 5 Î¼L. A digital camera was used to record the evolution of underwater wetting state of the CB-PTFE electrode.

All electrochemical experiments were conducted in a H-type two-compartment cell separated by cation-exchange membrane (CMI-7000, Membrane International Inc., USA) to preclude anodic oxidation of the cathodically generated H2O2. Na2SO4 solution (0.5 mol Lâ1) was used as the electrolyte (pH 7, buffered with phosphate) and was vigorously agitated with a magnetic stirring bar to achieve homogeneous solution. The as-prepared CB-PTFE electrode (2 cm Ã 5 cm) was used as the working electrode in the cathode compartment and the cathodic potentials were recorded versus a saturated calomel electrode (SCE, Leici Co., Shanghai, China). An iridium oxide coated titanium (Ti/IrO2, 2 cm Ã 5 cm) was used as the counter electrode in the anode compartment. All electrolysis processes were controlled using an electrochemical workstation (CHI 1140C, Shanghai Chenhua Co.).

Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) experiments were performed to evaluate the activity of the electrode for O2, H2O, and H2O2 reduction. LSV analysis of O2 reduction was evaluated in 0.5 mol Lâ1 Na2SO4 electrolytes in which a pure oxygen gas (99.9 %) was sparged at varying flow rates (0â¼1/2 L minâ1) using a porous bubble diffuser (average pore size of 10 Î¼m). H2O reduction (H2 evolution) was evaluated in electrolytes whose dissolved oxygen (DO) had been previously stripped by high-purity nitrogen gas (99.999 %) sparging. H2O2 reduction was also evaluated in the DO-stripped electrolytes in the presence of externally added H2O2.

Electrochemical H2O2 production with the CB-PTFE cathodes was evaluated at constant potentials controlled by the electrochemical workstation. A pure oxygen gas (99.9 %) was pre-sparged for 30 min before electrolysis and continuously sparged during electrolysis. DO concentrations were measured using a DO meter (Seven2Goâ¢, Mettler). H2O2 concentrations were measured with a UVâvis spectrophotometer (DR5000, HACH) using titanium potassium oxalate method [46]. The apparent current efficiency (ACE) for H2O2 production is calculated according to Eq. (1) [47].

Figs. 2 a-b show that when the CB-PTFE electrode is submerged in water, a silver mirror-like sheen appears at the electrode surface. This phenomenon is caused by the reflection of light from the air layer retained on the electrode surface and is a signature of the UC state [40,48]. As shown in Fig. 2b, a quasi-continuous gas film was retained on the CB-PTFE electrode surface when it was completely immersed in the water. This observation indicate that the CB-PTFE electrode has a high gas affinity and can thus entrap considerable amounts of air on its surface when it is immersed in water.

According to Xu et al. [42], a superaerophilic surface can be defined as a surface with an underwater bubble contact angle (BCA) lower than 10 Â°. Fig. 2c shows that the BCA at the CB-PTFE electrode surface is â¼8.8 Â°, which confirms that the CB-PTFE electrode is a superaerophilic electrode. The superaerophilicity of the electrode can be attributed to (i) the high roughness of its micro-/nanostructured surface, and (ii) the presence of superhydrophobic PTFE on its surface [40,41,49]. As shown in the SEM images (Figs. 2e-g), the macroscopically smooth CB-PTFE surface is actually very rough on a microscopic scale. The nano-sized carbon black particles (average size of 30 nm) and PTFE binder were mixed uniformly and bonded together, which results in numerous interconnected pores on the CB-PTFE electrode surface (see SI Fig. S2 for more information on the pore volume distribution of CB-PTFE electrode). Further analysis of the surface by AFM reveals a highly rugged surface with many sharply rising peaks (Fig. 2h). In addition, the AFM images of five randomly selected cross sections of the CB-PTFE surface show an irregular peak and valley structure (Fig. 2i). Based on the 3D topographic image in Fig. 2h, the average roughness of the surface is estimated to be 41.8 nm by the AFM measurement software. The high surface roughness is helpful to trap and stabilize air cushion when the electrode is immersed in water. In addition, PTFE is a highly hydrophobic material with a low surface energy of 18 mN mâ1 and melting point of 327 Â°C [50]. During electrode calcination at 350 Â°C, PTFE in the CB-PTFE mixture was melted and distributed evenly on the electrode surface (see SI Fig. S4 for the elemental mapping of fluorine), which can thus prevent water from seeping into the pores of the CB-PTFE electrode by capillary action. Consequently, the CB-PTFE electrode maintained a stable UC state even after it was immersed in the water for months. Notably, in previous pilot scale studies, it was found that CB-PTFE electrodes could retain a stable gas film on the electrode surface when they were submerged to a depth of 1.0â1.2 m underwater [7,51]. These observations suggest that within the typical range of electrode immersion depth used in water and wastewater treatment, the variation of hydraulic pressures does not considerably influence the wetting state of the CB-PTFE electrode [52,53].

ce:section.ce:section-title: Effects of cathodic polarization on electrode wetting state
ce:section.ce:para:
In contrast to the stable UC state under the unpolarized condition, the quasi-continuous gas film on the CB-PTFE electrode surface became progressively thinner and then completely disappeared in â¼30 s upon applying a constant potential of â1.0 V vs. SCE to the electrode (see Movie 1 in the Electronic Supporting Information (ESI)). This observation indicates that upon cathodic polarization, the wetting state of the CB-PTFE electrode changes quickly from the initial UC state to the UWC state, and finally to the UW state. These changes can be probably attributed to a combined result of two events that occur under the cathodic polarization conditions: (i) the consumption of trapped oxygen in ORR to H2O2, and (ii) the electrowetting effect. Due to the consumption of trapped oxygen in ORR, the gas pressure in the pores on the CB-PTFE electrode surface decreases, which facilitates the seepage of water into the pores. Moreover, according to the electrowetting theory, the contact angle between solid and liquid decreases upon cathodic polarization (Eq. 2, the Lippmann-Young Equation) [54,55], which also facilitates water intrusion into the pores of the CB-PTFE electrode. Due to the two effects, the gases (oxygen and nitrogen) entrapped at the textured surface of CB-PTFE electrode are continuously consumed and/or expelled from the pores, leading to a continuous change of the electrode wetting state from the initial UC state to the UWC state, and eventually to the UW state. This observation indicates that cathodic polarization can considerably influence the wetting state of superaerophilic electrodes.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Evolution of electrode wetting state during electrochemical H2O2 production
ce:section.ce:para: To evaluate the evolution of electrode wetting state during electrochemical H2O2 production, potentiostatic electrolysis (â1.0 V vs. SCE) with the CB-PTFE electrode and a pure oxygen gas sparging at a flow rate of 1/8 L minâ1 was performed. Similar to what has been observed during cathodic polarization (without oxygen sparging), the wetting state of the CB-PTFE electrode changed from the initial UC state to the UWC state, and finally to the UW state during electrochemical H2O2 production with the oxygen sparging (see Fig. 3 a). However, the change of wetting state proceeded considerably slower in the presence of sparged O2. After the initiation of electrolysis, the silver mirror-like sheen on the electrode surface darkened gradually (see Fig. 3a for the electrode photos at t = 0 and 100 s, respectively), which indicates a change of the UC state to the UWC state due to water intrusion into the pores of the CB-PTFE electrode (Fig. 3b). Later on, the quasi-continuous gas film on the electrode surface became gradually thinner, and finally disintegrated into isolated gas pockets (t = 1500 s, Fig. 3a), which suggests that some areas on the electrode surface have been completely wetted by the electrolyte. With further increasing the electrolysis time, all gas pockets on the electrode surface eventually disappeared (t > â¼2200 s, Fig. 3a), indicating a complete wetting of the electrode (the UW state).

Compared with cathodic polarization without oxygen sparging, the CB-PTFE electrode maintained a considerably longer UWC state during electrochemical H2O2 production with oxygen sparging. This difference can be attributed to the compensation of O2 gas consumed in ORR by the sparged O2, which helps to slow down the disappearance of gas film on the electrode surface. Nevertheless, it seems that under the test conditions (cathodic potential of â1.0 V vs. SCE and O2 sparging of 1/8 L minâ1), the rate of O2 consumption at the electrode is higher than that of O2 transfer from the electrolyte to the electrode. Therefore, the gas film became progressively thinner and eventually disappeared during the electrolysis process (Fig. 3a).

Notably, Fig. 3c shows that coincident with the transition of the electrode wetting state, currents changed considerably during the potentiostatic electrolysis process. During the transition of wetting state from the UC to UWC state, cathodic currents increased sharply to â¼380 mA in â¼30 s (stage I), then maintained at this high current plateau for â¼1900 s (stage II, Fig. 3c). The currents then exhibited a quick decrease in the period of â¼1900â2200 s (stage III, Fig. 3c), and finally stabilized at â¼100 mA until the end of the experiment (stage IV, Fig. 3c). The coincidences between the transition of electrode wetting state and the changes of cathodic currents at stages I and III highlight that the wetting state of superaerophilic electrode plays a critical role in ORR to H2O2.

Overall, the results shown in Fig. 3c demonstrate that significantly higher ORR currents can be obtained when the CB-PTFE electrode is in the UWC state than in the UC and UW state. This observation can be attributed to the fact that a significantly larger triple phase interface between the oxygen gas, electrode, and electrolyte can be obtained when the superaerophilic electrodes are in the UWC state than in the UC and UW state [40,41,49]. Under the UC state, the electrode surface is covered by a thick, quasi-continuous gas film (t = 0 s, Fig. 3a). Therefore, only the roughness peaks on the CB-PTFE electrode surface are in physical contact with the electrolyte (Fig. 3b), which results in high electron transfer resistance between the electrode and electrolyte [41]. Upon cathodic polarization, the electrolyte partially intrudes into the pores on the electrode surface (Fig. 3b), which increases considerably the solid/liquid/gas TPCL and thus reduces the charge transfer resistance. Consequently, the cathodic currents increased quickly during the transition of wetting state from the UC to UWC state (stage I, Fig. 3c).

During the transition of wetting state from the UWC to UW state, the currents decreased quickly (stage III, Fig. 3c). This decrease can be probably attributed to the disappearance of gas film/pockets on the CB-PTFE electrode surface (Fig. 3a), which dramatically decreases the rate of oxygen transfer from the electrolyte to the CB-PTFE electrode. During electrochemical H2O2 production with oxygen sparging, numerous oxygen microbubbles were generated in the electrolyte (see SI Fig. S5). In the UWC state, the CB-PTFE electrode surface exhibited a high gas affinity and could instantly adsorb approaching oxygen microbubbles into the gas film or gas pockets on the electrode surface (see Movie 2 in the ESI). The instant coalescence of oxygen microbubble with the gas film/pockets has been referred to as the bursting phenomenon and can greatly accelerate the mass transfer of oxygen from the electrolyte to electrode [40,41]. After coalescing with the surface gas film/pockets, the adsorbed oxygen can diffuse quickly via the interconnected pores at the electrode surface to the TPCL to facilitate ORR to H2O2. In contrast, after the gas film/pockets disappeared, the wetted CB-PTFE electrode exhibited a highly aerophobic surface with an underwater bubble contact angle of 151 Â° (see Fig. 2d). Consequently, the electrode can no longer adsorb approaching oxygen microbubbles (see ESI Movie 3). Because of the inefficient oxygen transfer and the lack of tri-phase interface in the UW state, the currents decreased significantly when the electrode wetting state changed from the UWC state to the UW state (stage III, see Fig. 3c).

The results shown above indicate that in the UWC state, the presence of gas film/pockets at the superaerophilic electrode surface can greatly facilitate the interfacial oxygen and electron transfer processes involved in ORR to H2O2. Consequently, high ORR currents can be obtained to enhance H2O2 production. As shown in Fig. 3d, H2O2 concentrations increased stably during electrolysis in the UWC state. In addition, nearly 100 % ACEs for H2O2 production were obtained during this period. This observation indicates that when the CB-PTFE electrode is in the UWC state, further reduction of H2O2 to H2O is negligible because the hydrophobic PTFE coating facilitates to repel the generated H2O2 away from the triple phase interface to the bulk liquid. However, both the H2O2 concentrations and ACEs for H2O2 production then decreased after the electrode wetting state was changed to the UW state. These decreases suggest that H2O2 reduction is substantially enhanced at the wetted CB-PTFE electrode because the water film (stagnant boundary layer) developed at the wetted electrode surface impedes the desorption process of generated H2O2 [49], thus leading to its further reduction to H2O. These observations indicate that the wetting state of carbon-based superaerophilic electrode can significantly influence the selectivity of the electrode for two- and four-electron ORR. Note that at the applied cathodic potential of â1.0 V vs. SCE, hydrogen evolution reaction (HRE) did not occur at the CB-PTFE electrode (see SI Fig. S6). Therefore, the decreases of ACEs for H2O2 production are mainly attributed to the reduction of H2O2 at the wetted electrode (see SI Fig. S7 for more information).

The results shown above indicate that during electrolysis with the superaerophilic electrodes, the electrode wetting state can change significantly, which will in turn influences the performance of H2O2 production considerably. Maintaining a stable UWC state is critical to enhance the kinetics and ACE of electrochemical H2O2 production with the superaerophilic electrodes.

The results shown in Fig. 3 suggest that with an oxygen sparging rate of 1/8 L minâ1, the oxygen consumed in ORR to H2O2 at the electrode cannot be sufficiently compensated by the oxygen transferred from the electrolyte. As a result, the electrode wetting state changed progressively from the UWC state toward the UW state. To further evaluate the effect of oxygen transfer on the evolution of electrode wetting state, potentiostatic electrolysis experiments (â1.0 V vs. SCE) with varying oxygen sparging rates (1/32â1/2 L minâ1) were performed. As shown in SI Fig. S8, similar dissolved oxygen (DO) concentrations (â¼43 mg Lâ1) were obtained during electrolysis with the varying oxygen sparging rates. Nevertheless, with increasing the oxygen sparging rates, more oxygen microbubbles were generated in the electrolytes (SI Fig. S5), which increases the chance of microbubble adsorption by the electrode surface and thus enhances the rate of oxygen transfer to the electrode.

Fig. 4 shows that cathodic currents exhibited significantly different dynamics during electrolysis with the varying oxygen sparging rates. When oxygen was sparged at a flow rate of 1/32â1/16 L minâ1, the currents increased quickly to â¼300â360 mA in the first 10â20 s (Fig. 4a and b), which indicates a transition of electrode wetting state from the UC to UWC state. However, the UWC state was only maintained for a short period (<1 min) and then changed to the UW state, as evidenced by the quick disappearance of gas film and the sharp decrease of ORR currents (Fig. 4a-d). Corresponding to the low currents in the UW state, H2O2 concentrations increased very slowly during electrolysis with 1/32â1/16 L minâ1 oxygen sparging (Fig. 4k). Moreover, the ACEs for H2O2 production were also considerably lower than 100 % (Fig. 4l), which indicates that H2O2 reduction occur considerably at the wetted CB-PTFE electrode surface (see SI Fig. S7).

In contrast, with an oxygen sparging rate of 1/4â1/2 L minâ1, the currents increased quickly to a plateau of â¼400â430 mA, which was then maintained stably until the end of the experiments (Fig. 4c, e). Notably, a quasi-continuous gas film was retained on the CB-PTFE electrode surface at the end of the electrolysis with 1/2 L minâ1 oxygen sparging (see Fig. 4j), although the thickness of the film decreased slightly compared to that in the original UC state (Fig. 3a). For the electrode with 1/4 L minâ1 oxygen sparging, a few breakages were observed on the gas film (Fig. 4h). Nevertheless, the predominant part of the electrode surface was still covered by a thin gas film. These observations indicate that the CB-PTFE electrodes are still in the UWC wetting state at the end of electrolysis with 1/4â1/2 L minâ1 oxygen sparging. Corresponding to the high currents in the UWC state, H2O2 concentrations increased quickly and linearly during electrolysis with 1/8â1/2 L minâ1 oxygen sparging (Fig. 4k). In addition, the ACEs for H2O2 production were generally maintained at â¼100 % during the process (Fig. 4l). Note that the ACEs decreased slightly at the late stage of electrolysis with 1/4 L minâ1 oxygen sparging, which can be possibly attributed to the reduction of H2O2 at the few wetted areas on the electrode surface.

Overall, the results presented above demonstrate that effective oxygen transfer to the electrode to sufficiently compensate oxygen gas consumed in ORR is critical to maintain the originally trapped gas film and thus keep the electrode wetting state in the UWC state during electrolysis with the superaerophilic CB-PTFE electrode. With increasing oxygen sparging rates to enhance oxygen transfer to the electrode, a stable UWC state can be possibly maintained to achieve stable and efficient H2O2 production during electrolysis with the CB-PTFE electrode.

It is noted that because the electrochemical reactor used in this lab study was open to the air, most oxygen bubbles in the solution escaped from the reactor due to gas buoyancy, which resulted in a low oxygen utilization efficiency (OUE) of H2O2 production (< 2.5 %, see SI Fig. S10 for the calculation). By improving the reactor configurations to enhance oxygen transfer to the cathode or recycling the escaped oxygen back to the reactor, the OUE of H2O2 production can probably be considerably increased (see SI for more discussion).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Mechanism of oxygen transfer in the UWC and UW state
ce:section.ce:para: The above results demonstrate that in addition to being used in the GDE (or natural air diffusion electrode NADE [37]) configuration, the superaerophilic CB-PTFE electrode can also be used in the SAE configuration for stable H2O2 production. Similar to the GDE, a stable G-L-S tri-phase is critical to maintaining effective oxygen transfer to the SAE for H2O2 production. Nevertheless, unlike the GDE and NADE, where oxygen gas diffuses from the aerophilic diffusion layer through internal pores of the electrode to the catalyst layer, the SAE utilizes oxygen microbubbles and dissolved oxygen (DO) in the water as the oxygen source for ORR. To evaluate the relative importance of oxygen microbubbles and DO for ORR at the superaerophilic CB-PTFE electrode, electrolysis in the presence and absence of sparged oxygen was compared (see Fig. 5 ).

Before the electrolysis, the electrolyte was sparged with 1/2 L minâ1 oxygen gas for 30 min to achieve the saturated DO concentration (â¼43 mg Lâ1). Following the initiation of electrolysis, the wetting state of CB-PTFE electrode changed quickly from the initial UC state to the UWC state, and a high current of â¼410 mA was obtained in the presence of sparged oxygen. However, the currents then decreased steeply to â¼30 mA when the oxygen sparging was temporarily turned off during electrolysis. Based on the different ORR currents observed in the presence and absence of sparged oxygen, it is estimated that the rates of oxygen transfer by microbubble adsorption and DO diffusion are â¼2.1 Ã 10â6 and 1.5 Ã 10â7 mol sâ1, respectively (see SI Eq. S5 for detailed calculations). These data confirm that when the electrode is in the UWC state, oxygen microbubbles are the predominant oxygen source of ORR, and the direct adsorption of oxygen microbubbles via the bursting phenomenon is the main mechanism of oxygen transfer to the electrode. In contrast, in the absence of oxygen microbubbles, DO diffusion alone cannot maintain a high ORR current due to the low solubility of oxygen and the low diffusivity of DO in water (44.4 mg Lâ1 and 2.01 Ã 10â9 m2 sâ1 at 20 Â°C [56]).

Interestingly, when the oxygen sparging was resumed after a 100 s of interruption, the current increased almost instantly back to â¼410 mA and then maintained at the high plateau until the end of the experiment (Fig. 5a). In contrast, the current was only partially recovered and then decreased continuously if the interruption period was extended to 400 s (Fig. 5b). This difference can be probably attributed to the fact that during the interruption of oxygen sparging, O2 in the originally trapped gas film is continuously consumed in ORR, which results in a progressive water intrusion into the electrode pores and the transition of the electrode wetting state from the UWC to UW state [57,58]. After the shorter break of 100 s, the electrode still retained some gas pockets in its pores, which facilitates the adsorption of approaching oxygen microbubbles when the oxygen sparging was resumed. Therefore, the ORR currents could be quickly restored to the previous plateau (Fig. 5a). However, when the interruption was extended to 400 s, the gas pockets largely disappeared on the CB-PTFE electrode, which significantly decreases the ability of the electrode to adsorb approaching oxygen microbubbles. Hence, although the oxygen sparging was resumed after the 400 s interruption, insufficient oxygen microbubbles could be adsorbed by the electrode to fully restore the currents back to the previous plateau. Furthermore, due to the inefficient oxygen transfer to the largely wetted electrode, the pores of the CB-PTFE electrode were then progressively flooded by water, leading to a further transition of the electrode wetting state toward the UW state. Consequently, the currents decreased continuously as the electrolysis process proceeded (Fig. 5b). Overall, the results presented in Fig. 5 highlight that continuous feeding O2 to ensure the aerophilic layer is critical for maintaining stable and effective H2O2 production with the superaerophilic electrode, which is also the proven reason of the outperforming air-diffusion electrodes.

Parenthetically, SI Fig. S11 shows that after the CB-PTFE electrode was completely transformed to the UW state, oxygen sparging rates had minimal effects on the ORR currents, which stabilized at â¼15 mA regardless of the varying oxygen sparging rates of 1/32â1/2 L minâ1. This observation suggests that when the CB-PTFE electrode is completely wetted, DO is the main oxygen source of ORR since the wetted surface is no longer effective at adsorbing oxygen microbubbles.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Electrochemical H2O2 production in the UWC and UW state
ce:section.ce:para: Fig. 6 a shows that when a fresh CB-PTFE electrode was used during electrolysis with 1/2 L minâ1 oxygen gas sparging, it maintained high ACEs for H2O2 production (â¼100 %) over a wide potential range from â0.5 to â2.5 V vs. SCE. Note that a fresh CB-PTFE electrode was used to obtain each data point shown in Fig. 6a. Upon cathodic polarization at the varying potentials, the fresh electrodes changed quickly from the initial UC state to the UWC state, which was then maintained stably throughout the experiments (similar to that shown in Fig. 4i). According to Eq. (2), decreasing cathodic potentials to more negative regions will decrease the contact angle between the electrode and water (Î¸), thus facilitating electrode wetting by the electrocapillary effect [54,55]. Moreover, as the cathodic potentials decrease, side reactions such as H2O reduction and H2O2 reduction may be promoted [1,2]. Therefore, it had been expected that the ACEs for H2O2 production might decrease as the cathodic potentials were decreased from â0.5 to â2.5 V vs. SCE. However, the results shown in Fig. 6 indicate that because of the effective oxygen transfer at the high oxygen gas sparging (1/2 L minâ1), the CB-PTFE electrode could still maintain a stable UWC state during electrolysis with even a very negative cathodic potential of â2.5 V vs. SCE. The high ACEs obtained at the varying potentials highlight that when the CB-PTFE is in the UWC state, two-electron ORR to H2O2 is the predominant cathodic reaction, whereas side reactions such as H2O reduction and H2O2 reduction are negligible. Consequently, for a charge loading of 50 C, â¼22 mg Lâ1 of H2O2 could be obtained with the CB-PTFE electrode in the UWC state (Fig. 6a).

In contrast, when a completely wetted CB-PTFE electrode (obtained by pre-polarizing a fresh electrode at â1 V vs. SCE without O2 gas sparging for 10 min) was used during electrolysis with 1/2 L minâ1 oxygen gas sparging, significantly lower H2O2 concentrations (â¼0.8â7.2 mg Lâ1) and ACEs (5.0â32.7 %) were obtained for the same charge loading (50 C) (Fig. 6b). In the potential range of â0.5 to â1.0 V vs. SCE, where HER cannot occur, the decrease of H2O2 concentrations and ACEs can be mainly attributed to the reduction of electro-generated H2O2 at the wetted electrode (see Fig. S7). In contrast, both H2O2 reduction and H2O reduction can occur in the cathodic potential range of â1.5 to â2.5 V vs. SCE, which resulted in further decreases in the H2O2 concentrations and ACEs for H2O2 production (Fig. 6b).

Overall, the results shown in Fig. 6 suggest that besides influencing oxygen transfer, the electrode wetting state also have a significant effect on the selectivity of electrode reactions. Corresponding to the change from the UWC state to the UW state, the ACEs for H2O2 production decreased considerably (Figs. 6a and b), which indicates a significant decrease in the selectivity of two-electron ORR at the wetted electrode. This decrease can be possibly mainly attributed to the change in the ease at which electro-generated H2O2 is transported away from the catalyst surface [1,49]. When the electrode is in the UWC state, electro-generated H2O2 will be quickly expelled from the triple-phase interface to the bulk liquid due to the high hydrophobicity of PTFE, which prevents its further reduction to H2O. In contrast, when the electrode is in the UW state, electro-generated H2O2 has to diffuse thorough the liquid film (stagnant boundary layer) developed at the wetted electrode surface before it is transported to the bulk liquid. Due to the slow diffusion of H2O2 in the stagnant boundary layer, electro-reduction of H2O2 to H2O is enhanced at the wetted electrode surface, leading to substantial decreases in the ACEs for H2O2 production.

Due to the lower ORR currents and ACEs for H2O2 production in the UW state, H2O2 concentrations increased at a significantly lower rate (25.4 mg Lâ1 hâ1) during potentiostatic electrolysis (â1.0 V vs. SCE) with the wetted CB-PTFE electrode compared to that with the virgin electrode (615.5 mg Lâ1 hâ1) (see SI Table S1). Moreover, once the wetting state of the CB-PTFE electrode is changed to the UW state, it is unlikely to restore it back to the UWC state by increasing the oxygen sparging rates during the electrolysis process because the wetted surface has a low adhesion force to adsorb oxygen bubbles. Nevertheless, after the wetted CB-PTFE electrode dried out in the air, the electrode fully recovered its superaerophilicity and performed essentially the same as the virgin electrode during electrolysis. As shown in Fig. 7 , for the same input charge loading, the concentrations of H2O2 and ACE for H2O2 production were essentially the same during electrolysis with the virgin and air-dried CB-PTFE electrode. These observations indicate that by simply drying the wetted CB-PTFE electrode in the air, the superaerophilicity of the electrode can be fully recovered for effective H2O2 production.

Electrode characterizations using SEM, EDS, N2 adsorption, and mercury intrusion techniques show that there were insignificant changes in the surface morphology, elemental composition, and pore size distribution between the virgin and air-dried CB-PTFE electrodes (see SI Fig. S2â4 for detailed information). These observations suggest that during electrochemical H2O2 production, the reaction between H2O2 and electrode surface was insignificant and thus did not considerably change the physicochemical properties and wetting behavior of CB-PTFE electrodes. These results can be probably attributed to (i) the repelling of H2O2 from the superhydrophobic electrode surface, and (ii) the so-called âcathodic protectionâ effect, that is, upon cathodic polarization, considerable amounts of net electrons accumulate at the CB-PTFE electrode surface, which can largely prevent CB from being oxidized by the electro-generated H2O2 [59,60]. Therefore, it usually takes much longer experiment time (e.g., several tens and hundreds of hours) before H2O2-oxidation induced changes can be discerned in the physicochemical properties of CB-PTFE electrode [61]. Overall, the results presented herein suggest that within the timeframe of the experiments, the intrinsic wettability and other physicochemical properties of CB-PTFE electrode does not change considerably. Therefore, the variations of H2O2 production performance can be mainly attributed to the dynamic changes of gas film/pockets at the electrode surface, which can in turn significantly influence the mechanism of oxygen transfer and the selectivity of electrode reactions during electrolysis with the superaerophilic electrodes.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Maintaining stable UWC state for H2O2 production
ce:section.ce:para: To evaluate the evolution of electrode wetting state under conditions more representative of real applications, electro-generation of H2O2 was conducted under galvanostatic electrolysis conditions for 12 h. When a current density of 10 mA cmâ2 was applied, the CB-PTFE electrode retained a quasi-continuous gas film on its surface after 12 h of electrolysis (see Fig. 8 c). In comparison, the gas film was thinner and discontinuous at a few places in the bottom-right corner of the electrode after 12 h of electrolysis with 20 mA cmâ2 (Fig. 8d). These observations indicate that a stable UWC state was maintained during the 12 h of electrolysis with 10 mA cmâ2. However, a few areas of the electrode surface changed to the UW state during electrolysis with 20 mA cmâ2 (Fig. 8d).

As discussed previously, the electrode wetting state would either maintain the UWC state or change to the UW state depending on whether the trapped oxygen consumed in ORR could be sufficiently compensated by the oxygen transferred to the electrode during electrolysis. According to the Faradayâs electrolysis law (Eq. 3), the rate of oxygen consumption in ORR was estimated to be â¼5.1 Ã 10â7 and 1.0 Ã 10â6 mol sâ1 during electrolysis with 10 and 20 mA cmâ2, respectively.
(3)
r =
j Î· S
n F
where r is the rate of oxygen consumption in ORR (mol sâ1), j is ORR current density (A cmâ2), Î· is the ACE for H2O2 production (%), S is the electrode surface area (cm2), n is the electron transfer number for one O2 molecule reduction to H2O2 (n = 2), F is Faraday constant (96,485 C molâ1). These data suggest that under the testing conditions (oxygen gas sparging rate of 0.75 L minâ1), â¥5.1 Ã 10â7 mol sâ1 of oxygen could be transported to the CB-PTFE electrode, thus maintaining the electrode in the UWC state during electrolysis with 10 mA cm2 (Fig. 8c). However, the rate of oxygen transfer is probably slightly lower than 1.0 Ã 10â6 mol sâ1. Consequently, a few places on the electrode surface changed to the UW state during electrolysis with 20 mA cmâ2 (Fig. 8d).

During the 12 h of electrolysis, H2O2 concentrations increased continuously, while ACEs for H2O2 production decreased gradually (Fig. 8). The decrease of ACEs can be possibly attributed to the fact that as H2O2 concentrations increase, the reduction of H2O2 at the cathode and self-decomposition of H2O2 in the water are enhanced [9]. However, a high ACE of â¼88 % was still obtained at the end of electrolysis with 10 mA cmâ2. This observation corroborates that when the CB-PTFE electrode is in the UWC state, reduction of H2O2 to H2O is not severe at even very high H2O2 concentrations of â¼3500 mg Lâ1. Consequently, H2O2 concentrations increased almost linearly during electrolysis with 10 mA cmâ2 (Fig. 8a). In comparison, a lower ACE (â¼80 %) was obtained at the end of electrolysis with 20 mA cmâ2, and the curves of H2O2 concentrations and ACEs exhibited a slight inflection at 6 h, which can be possibly attributed to the enhanced reduction of H2O2 at the few wetted areas on the electrode surface.

Overall, the results of this study demonstrate that when the superaerophilic CB-PTFE electrode is in the UWC state, it can effectively enhance oxygen transfer by directly adsorbing oxygen microbubbles aerated in the water. This considerably alleviates the limitation of oxygen mass transfer on the rate of H2O2 production during electrolysis with the SAE setup. To prevent the electrode wetting state from changing from the UWC state to the UW state, the rates of O2 consumption and transfer have to carefully controlled during electrolysis with the superaerophilic CB-PTFE electrode. According to Eq. (3), the rate of O2 consumption in ORR is mainly determined by the applied current density during electrolysis. On the other hand, the rate of O2 transfer is dependent on many factors, such as oxygen gas sparging rate, the distance between the electrode and gas diffuser, and electrode orientation [10,62]. As shown in Fig. 8a, the CB-PTFE electrode maintained a stable UWC state for 12 h during electrolysis with 10 mA cmâ2 and oxygen gas sparging rate of 0.75 L minâ1. This finding suggests that by carefully optimizing applied current densities, oxygen sparging rates, and other process parameters, it is possible to maintain a stable UWC state for maximizing H2O2 production during electrolysis with superaerophilic SAEs.

The results of this study demonstrate that during electrolysis, the wetting state of superaerophilic CB-PTFE electrodes changes dynamically and can significantly influence the performance of H2O2 production from ORR. Due to the high surface roughness and hydrophobicity of PTFE, the CB-PTFE electrode exhibited a superaerophilic property and retained a quasi-continuous gas film at its porous surface when it was immersed in water. Upon cathodic polarization, water partially intruded into the pores of the CB-PTFE electrode, resulting in a quick change of the electrode wetting state from the initial UC state to the UWC state. The water intrusion increased the triple phase interface between the electrode, gas, and electrolyte (solid/liquid/gas tri-phase TPCL), which facilitates the interfacial electron transfer processes involved in ORR to H2O2. In addition, the presence of gas film on the electrode surface significantly enhanced oxygen transfer by directly adsorbing oxygen microbubbles aerated in the electrolyte (the bursting phenomenon). Furthermore, the presence of gas film effectively inhibited the further reduction of H2O2 to H2O at the electrode surface. Therefore, high ORR currents and ACEs of H2O2 production could be obtained during electrolysis with the CB-PTFE electrode in the UWC state.

Nevertheless, in case the oxygen consumed in ORR cannot be sufficiently compensated by the oxygen transferred to the electrode (e.g., during electrolysis with a low oxygen sparging rate), the gas film on the electrode surface became progressively thinner and eventually disappeared. Meanwhile, water intruded progressively into the pores of the electrode, resulting in a transition of the UWC wetting state to the UW state. After the gas film/pockets on the electrode surface disappeared, the wetted electrode exhibited a low gas affinity and was ineffective at adsorbing oxygen microbubbles. Moreover, the reduction of H2O2 was considerably enhanced at the wetted electrode surface. Correspondingly, ORR currents and ACEs for H2O2 production decreased dramatically in the UW state due to the slow diffusion of dissolved oxygen to the electrode. The results of this study indicate that the evolution of electrode wetting state plays a critical role in H2O2 production from ORR during electrolysis with the superaerophilic electrodes. By carefully controlling the applied current density and other process parameters (e.g., oxygen gas sparing rate) to balance the rates of oxygen consumption and transfer, a stable UWC state can be maintained to maximize H2O2 production during electrolysis with the superaerophilic CB-PTFE electrode.
